choices.text: Volume that remains after forced expiration

questions.solution:
Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.

From the picture given below, (FRC = ERV + RV).

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath.

Lung volumes, capacities, and their combinations are being tested year after year in the various competitive exams.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is breathing quietly. He then inhales as much air as possible and exhales as much air as he can, producing the spirogram shown in the figure. What is his expiratory reserve volume (in liters)?
questions.solution:
Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity - Residual Volume

In the given spirogram,

  • Functional Residual Capacity = 3L
  • Residual Volume = 1L 

Therefore,

Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity – Residual Volume = 3-1 = 2

Note:

The residual volume is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after the most forceful expiration.

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume plus the residual volume. This capacity is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration

The expiratory reserve volume is the maximum extra volume of air that can be expired by forceful expiration after the end of a normal tidal expiration.

questions.text: A nurse in the pulmonology clinic administered a test using the following instrument. Which of the following parameters cannot be measured?
questions.solution:
The given image shows spirometry. All of the given parameters can be measured by a spirometer except residual volume.

Residual volume is measured by:

  • N2 washout method
  • Helium-dilution method
  • Body plethysmography

Other parameters which cannot be measured by spirometry are:

  • Functional residual capacity
  • Total lung capacity

Total lung capacity depends on the distensibility of lungs (compliance).

Determinants of Lung Compliance

  • Stretchability of the lung tissues, particularly their elastic connective tissue.
  • Surface tension at the air-water interfaces within the alveoli, which is markedly reduced in the alveoli by pulmonary surfactant preventing their collapse.

Option b: The Closing Volume is the lung volume above Residual Volume at which airways in the lower, dependent parts of the lungs begin to close off because of the lesser transmural pressure in these areas.

Related Pearl: Pulmonary surfactant

It lowers the surface tension of the water layer at the alveolar surface, which increases lung compliance, thereby making it easier for the lungs to expand. It is secreted by type II alveolar cells. It is a mixture of phospholipids and protein.

4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: Surfactant proteins are (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

  • SP-A - Regulation of the feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveolar epithelial cells that secrete it.
  • SP-B & SP-C - Key protein members of the monomolecular film of surfactant.
  • SP-D - Organization of SP-B and SP-C into the surfactant layer.

A deep breath increases its secretion by stretching the type II cells. Its concentration decreases when breaths are small.

In the fetus, surfactant synthesis is variable. The surfactant may be present as early as gestational week 24 and is almost always present by gestational week 35.

questions.text: Single breath nitrogen method is used for measuring ____
questions.solution:
Anatomical dead space can be measured by the single-breath N2 curve (Fowler's method).

  • Anatomical dead space is the respiratory system volume exclusive of alveoli.
  • Alveolar dead space is the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood i.e. wasted ventilation.
  • Physiological/total dead space is the sum of anatomical and alveolar dead space.
  • The equation used for the calculation of total/physiological dead space is the Bohr’s equation.

The patient takes a deep breath of O2 From mid-inspiration, then exhales steadily. The changes in the N2 concentration of expired gas during expiration are plotted.

Region I - Dead Space (DS)

From I–II is a mixture of DS and alveolar gas.

The transition from III-IV is the closing volume (CV).

End of IV - Residual Volume (RV).

questions.text: Calculate the alveolar ventilation in a young man if the respiratory rate is 10/min and tidal volume is 600ml.
questions.solution:
Alveolar ventilation = RR X (VT –V D)

In the given case,

  • Respiratory rate (RR)= 10/min
  • Tidal volume (VT) = 600 mL
  • Dead space volume (VD) = 150 mL in a young man

Thus, Alveolar ventilation = 10 X (600-150) = 4500 mL/min = 4.5 L/min

questions.text: Normal VD(Dead space volume)/ VT (Tidal volume) is_____
questions.solution:
• Dead space volume = VD = 150ml
  • Tidal volume = VT = 500ml
  • Normal VD/VT = 150/500 = 0.3

questions.text: A patient has a dead space of 150 mL, a functional residual capacity of 3L, tidal volume of 650 mL, expiratory reserve volume of 1.5 L, a total lung capacity of 8L, respiratory rate of 15 breaths/min. What is the rate of alveolar ventilation?
questions.solution:
The rate of alveolar ventilation in this patient is 7.5 L/min.

Alveolar ventilation per minute is the total volume of new air entering the alveoli and adjacent gas exchange areas each minute. It is equal to the respiratory rate times the amount of new air that enters these areas with each breath.

Alveolar ventilation=Respiratory rate X (Tidal volume – Physiologic dead space)

                               = 15 X (650-150)

                               = 7500mL/min or 7.5L/min.

questions.text: Closing volume of the lung is_____

choices.text: Above residual volume in upper portions of the lungs
Above the residual volume in dependent portions of the lungs
Above tidal volume in dependent portions of the lungs
Above tidal volume in upper portions of the lungs

questions.solution:
The closing volume (CV) is the lung volume above the residual volume (RV) at which the airways in the lower dependent parts of the lung begin to close off because of the lesser transmural pressure in these areas.

In young adults, the closing volume is about 10% of the vital capacity (VC). It increases steadily with age and is equal to about 40% of the VC. It equals FRC, at about the age of 65 years.

Diseases of the small airways apparently increase the closing volume

  • Normal young adult: CV << FRC
  • At 65 years of age: CV=FRC
  • Small airway disease: CV >>FRC
  • In case of hyaline membrane disease, FRC is smaller than closing volume.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presented with gradually progressive dyspnea and a non-productive cough. On examination, he has bi-basilar inspiratory crackles and clubbing. Which of the following pulmonary function tests will be true if he is to be diagnosed with interstitial pulmonary fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Interstitial pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease that shows ↑FEV1/FVC, ↓Compliance when performing pulmonary function tests.

In a healthy normal adult male, FVC is approximately 5.0 L, FEV1 is approximately 4.0 L, and thus, the calculated FEV1/FVC is 80%.

Obstructive disorders result in a marked decrease in both FVC and FEV1/FVC, whereas restrictive disorders result in a loss of FVC without loss in FEV1/FVC.

Compliance is reduced in cases of restrictive lung diseases. For example - interstitial lung diseases, fibrosis, sarcoidosis, asbestosis, and radiation exposure.

The inspiratory flow-volume curve is truncated in patients with variable extrathoracic obstructions.

  • During a forced expiration, the cross-sectional area of a variable extrathoracic obstruction increases as the pressure inside the airway increases.
  • The expiratory flow-volume curve is therefore nearly normal or not affected.
  • However, during a forced inspiration, the pressure inside the upper airway decreases below atmospheric pressure, and unless the stability of the upper airway is maintained by reflex contraction of the pharyngeal muscles or by other structures, the cross-sectional area of the upper airway will decrease. Therefore, the inspiratory flow-volume curve is truncated in patients with variable extrathoracic obstructions.
  • Flow-volume curves are very useful in assessing obstructions of upper airways and the trachea (refer figure and flowchart).

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the changes in lung volume and thoracic volume in a case of pneumothorax, compared to normal?
questions.solution:
In pneumothorax, lung volume is decreased and thoracic volume is increased.

Both lungs and the chest wall (thoracic cage) are elastic structures. Under normal conditions, the elastic tendency of the lungs to collapse is exactly balanced by the elastic tendency of the chest wall to expand.

In pneumothorax, air is introduced into the pleural space, so the pleural pressure, which is normally subatmospheric, becomes equal to atmospheric pressure. The chest wall springs outward and the lungs collapse. This increases the thoracic volume and decreases the lung volume.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man inhaled as much air as possible and then expired with a maximum effort until no more air could be expired. This produced the maximum expiratory flow-volume curve shown in the following diagram. What is the forced vital capacity of this man (in liters)?
questions.solution:
The forced vital capacity of this man is 4.5 liters.

The forced vital capacity (FVC), the largest amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort, is frequently measured clinically as an index of pulmonary function. 

Forced vital capacity(FVC) = Total lung capacity (TLC) – Residual volume(RV)

  • In the flow-volume curve, the point of intersection between abscissa and flow-volume curve gives the TLC and RV.
  • From the given flow-volume curve we can note that:
    • Total Lung Capacity (TLC) = 5.5 L
    • Residual volume (RV)= 1.0 L
  • Thus,
    • FVC = TLC – RV = 4.5 L

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman presents with cough and shortness of breath. The physician conducts a pulmonary function screening test in his office, and the patient generates the maximum expiratory flow–volume curve shown to the right of the normal curve in the diagram below. These findings are consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This is a case of asbestosis.

Asbestosis is a restrictive lung disease characterized by diffuse interstitial fibrosis. In restrictive lung disease, the maximum expiratory flow volume (MEFV) curve begins and ends at abnormally low lung volumes.

Note: In obstructive lung diseases, the airways are narrowed or radial traction of the airways is reduced, allowing them to close more easily. The lung volumes in these cases are higher than normal.

questions.text: The maximum expiratory flow-volume (MEFV) curves shown in the figure below were obtained from a healthy man (purple curve) and a 57-year-old man with shortness of breath (green curve). What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The green curve in the above image and the case scenario denotes that the diagnosis is likely to be emphysema.

Maximum expiratory flow volume (MEFV): When a person expires with great force, the expiratory airflow reaches a maximum flow beyond which the flow cannot be increased anymore, even with greatly increased additional force.

In obstructive airway disease like Emphysema, it is usually much more difficult to expire than to inspire because the closing tendency of the airways is greatly increased by the extra positive pressure during expiration. Due to the obstruction of the airways and because they collapse more easily than normal airways, the maximum expiratory flow rate is greatly reduced (But, total lung capacity and residual volume is increased) which is shown in the green curve below. 

Other options given above will cause constricted lungs where the lungs cannot expand to a normal maximum volume. Hence, even with the greatest possible expiratory effort, the maximum expiratory flow rate will be reduced. (Note: here both the total lung capacity and the residual volume are reduced), which is shown as the blue curve in the graph below.

questions.text:
Which of the following increases in COPD?
  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
In COPD, the functional residual capacity increases. Total lung capacity may be increased or normal. Hence, both 1 and 2 are correct.

  • In obstructive lung diseases, both FEV1 and FVC reduces, where the decrease in FEV1 is more than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases.
  • The total lung capacity is usually normal in chronic bronchitis, while increased in emphysema.
  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. In COPD, FRC is increased.
     

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most likely to stimulate ventilation after strenuous exercise?

choices.text: Collateral impulses from higher than brain centres

questions.solution:
The stimulus to ventilation after strenuous exercise is increased mean arterial H+.

The respiratory rate after exercise does not reach a basal level until the O2 debt is repaid. The stimulus for ventilation is increased mean arterial H+ due to an increase in blood lactic acid levels. Most of the lactic acid is converted to glycogen and some amount is converted to CO2 and H2O.
